history.content: Having taken both, I would say that EE16A definitely has more work. The weekly psets are super long, plus there's the 3-hour labs, discussions, etc. There is a lot of overlap in linear algebra content, but I think either one with your schedule would be doable

children.subject: I agree with the student answer. Math 54 is harder than EE16A, but EE16A is more work (especially if you have an 8am lab).
I'm not sure if you can if 16a is easier/harder than 54 (it depends on the person), but 54 is for sure less work.

Thanks for the info! I got a 5 on Physics C E&M. Would the circuits knowledge from that be applicable to 16B? I've already planned out 16 units for this fall, so I'm trying to be careful with any changes.

Anon again: I haven't taken E&M, but I understand the content from that class is rather physics-based, whereas 16A is NOT a physics course. It can be seen as more of a DESIGN course, with regards to circuits. That being said, they teach circuits in quite a different way, and present you with increasingly complicated circuits and higher-level design questions rather than emphasizing calculation-heavy questions that AP E&M asks. 

Still, you will probably have an easier time getting used to the symbols and notation involved with the circuits portion of 16A. I would probably advice you to take 16A (if it fits your schedule), since it seems you have the prior knowledge to make it a bit easier, but you still have much to gain from the course (plus, otherwise you'll miss out on the labs, which were my favorite part of the course, and I personally don't like EE topics!). 

However, I do understand the difficulty of scheduling, as I have dropped courses simply because of an awkward schedule/outside commitments. Your schedule can really be a game-changer in how well you absorb the material. Take 16A if you can, but you'll be fine either way imo.

I took EE 16A instead of 54, but it seems like with your background in math 54 may be easier (your background may not help specifically with linear algebra but at least the diff. eq. will probably be review for you). Keep in mind the entirety of EE 16A will probably be new material for you, unless you have experience with circuits/linear algebra, not to mention it requires a lot of time on HW and in lab.

On the flip side, if you take 54 and do not plan to also take EE 16A, before you get to EE 16B you will have to take EECS 47D to learn the EE16A circuits material you never learned. I haven't taken 47D, but It's typically advised that CS-intended students take EE 16A, and it seems like slightly less work overall.

history.content:
Which is more difficult/time consuming? I'm planning on taking CS61A + MATH54/EE16A + BIOENG 10 + POLSCI 5, probably P/NP-ing the breadths.

Incoming LSCS-intended freshman with relatively strong math background (5 on BC, took MVC and diffeq in HS) and minimal CS experience (5 on AP CS A). I'm leaning toward 54 mostly because it also satisfies a Haas prereq (AP cred no applicable), but I don't want to be studying all day.
history.subject: MATH54 vs EE16A
